Yes, there have been scientific studies on the experience of speaking in tongues. Researchers have used brain imaging techniques such as functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) and electroencephalography (EEG) to study changes in brain activity during the experience of speaking in tongues.

One study conducted at the University of Pennsylvania found that when people speak in tongues, there is increased activity in certain areas of the brain related to emotion, language, and motor control. This suggests that the experience of speaking in tongues involves complex neural activity, rather than being a meaningless or fake expression.

However, some critics argue that these studies do not provide conclusive evidence for the spiritual nature of the experience of speaking in tongues, as they can be interpreted in a number of ways. Additionally, since different religious traditions have different beliefs and practices regarding speaking in tongues, it can be difficult to generalize across all expressions of this phenomenon.
